25

$1+3+@5+7+@9

13579

^d // end-of-file

4.2.4 Grammar Symbols

Symbols in Upgen grammars represent the grammatical classification of the language. There are two types of symbols: Tokens (also known as terminal symbols, or terminals for short), Nonterminals (also known as Variables, syntactic categories). Tokens are primitive symbols; and nonterminals are described recursively in terms of each other nonterminals and tokens.

  1. Token declarations

There four types of token declarations which begin with keywords: %token, %left, %right and %nonassoc respectively. Following table shows you the differences among them:

Keyword

Associativity of tokens

Precedence of tokens

%token

undefined

undefined

%left

left-associative

according to tokens’ appearances, lowest first, highest last; the same in the same declaration

%right

right-associative

%nonassoc

forbidden

undefined


The syntax of token declaration is:

keyword [<a-member-of-SVT>] list-of-token-names

Keyword is one of keywords: %token, %left, %right and %nonassoc; a-member-of-SVT is one of name declared in SVT declaration and is optional; list-of-token-names are token names separated with blanks (each of them is either a white-space or a tab).

If <a-member-of-SVT> is presented, tokens in list-of-token-names are tagged, or untagged otherwise (including undeclared tokens).

There are two kinds of token names in the grammar:

  1. Named tokens

The type of named tokens is written as an identifier. Lexical convention for this kind of tokens is the same as the one for pattern names (see Section 4.2.2 Pattern Names). By convention, it should be all upper case.

  1. Character tokens

There are three ways to write a character token type (or literal character token): a literal, octal and hexadecimal character quoted by single quotation marks. For example, ‘+’, ‘\x2b’, ‘\X2B’, ‘\X2b’, ‘\x2B’, ‘\053’, are all character token type. All the usual escape sequences used in character literals in C/C++ can be used in Upgen as well, but you must not use the null character (‘\0’) as a character literal because its value, zero is the value of special token $end, which signifies end-of-input. Beside, for a quoted string that contains a back slash followed a character which is not one of the following characters:

‘ “ 0 ? \ a b f n r t v

it is equivalent to the string without back slash. For instance, ‘\+’ is equivalent to ‘+’. A character token doesn’t need to be declared unless you want to specify its semantic value, associativity, or precedence.

There are three special tokens: $end, error, $undefined. Token $end indicates there are no more tokens returned by scanner; token error is a special token to construct error recovery rules; token $undefined signifies that a token returned by scanner is not declared in declaration section and not used in grammar section if it is a character token. The value of $end, error, $undefined are 0, 256, 257, respectively. All of special these tokens should not serve any other purposes.


  1. Nonterminal declarations

The way to declare nonterminals is

%type < a-member-of-SVT > list-of-nonterminal-names

%type is a reserved word for grammar nonterminal declarations; a-member-of-SVT is one of name declared in semantic value type declaration; list-of-nonterminal-names are nonterminal names separated with blanks (each of them is either a white-space or a tab). Lexical convention for nonterminals is the same as the one for pattern names (see Section 4.2.2 Pattern Names). By convention, it should be capitalized word.

Nonterminals need not to be declared unless a semantic value is needed for them in grammar actions.

4.2.5 Start Symbol of Grammar

The declaration of start symbol begins with keyword %start, and its syntax is

%start start-symbol

For example, the line

%start Source

declares nonterminal Source to be the start symbol of the grammar. Apparently, start-symbol must be a left side symbol of some productions in grammar section.

Upgen takes the nonterminal from the first start symbol declaration as the start symbol, and will emit warning messages of duplication of start symbols if there are more than one start symbol declarations in declaration section. On the other hand, if there is no a start symbol declaration in declaration section at all, then Upgen takes it as the start symbol the left side nonterminal of the first grammar rule in grammar section. It is recommended that the start symbol should be declared explicitly.

4.2.6 Arguments for yyparse/yylex

Function yyparse is the controlling function for parsing; and function yylex is the controlling function for scanning. By default, yyparse/yylex has no arguments. But in many applications, arguments for yyparse/yylex are very useful; for example, they can be used to control interaction between the parser and the scanner.

The way to specify arguments for yyparse/yylex is

%formal-param%{ list-of-formal-arguments %}

%actual-param%{ list-of-actual-arguments %}

%formal-param is the keyword to declare formal arguments of yyparse/yylex; and %actual-param is the keyword to declare actual arguments of yyparse/yylex. List-of-formal-arguments is a list of formal arguments in target language and list-of-actual-arguments is a list of actual arguments in target language. For most programming language, both of formal arguments and actual arguments are needed syntactically.

Taking C++ as an example, if there are %formal-param and %actual-param declarations to specify arguments for yyparse/yylex, then the prototypes of yyparse/yylex will be

int yyparse(list-of-formal-arguments);

int yylex(list-of-formal-arguments);

Invocation of them in C++ will be

yyparse(list-of-actual-arguments);

yylex(list-of-actual-arguments);

The arguments also influence another function and two types. The function is error report routine, whose signature in C++ is

void yyerror(const char *msg, list-of-formal-arguments);

The two types are: yyerror_t, a pointer-to-procedure type whose signature is the same as error report routine; yylex_t, also a pointer-to-function type whose signature is the same as yylex.

In fact, both yyerror and yylex are considered as built-in functions; they can be replaced by user-defined functions which are instances of yyerror_t and yylex_t, respectively. To install user-defined version of them, call built-in functions yyseterror and yysetlex before calling yyparse. Here are prototypes of yyseterror and yysetlex:

yyerror_t yyseterror(yyerror_t);

yylex_t yysetlex(yylex_t);

For more details about them, see Section 5.1.5 Interface Functions.

4.2.7 SVT (Semantic Value Type)

SVT (semantic value type) is a collection of semantic values. There are two ways to declare SVT: two-step method and one-step method.

  1. Two-step method

This method divides declaration into two steps: first declaring data type for semantic values in target language; and then ‘assigning’ the data type to be semantic value type using a form of %union declaration. The syntax of the declaration is:

%union name-of-data-type-declared-in-target-language

For example, suppose there is a grammar whose symbols are either integer type or string type and the target language is C++. The steps of declaration of SVT are: first defining a compound data type, say, union symbol_t in definition header, and then specifying SVT to be symbol_t using %union declaration.

%{

union symbol_t {

int nVal;

char *pszVal;

};

%}


%union symbol_t


  1. One-step method

The second method uses keyword %union followed by declaration body of SVT enclosed in ‘%{‘ and ‘%}’:

%union%{

declaration body of semantic value type in target language

%}

For the grammar in last example, its SVT can also be declared:

%union%{

int nVal;

char *pszVal;

%}

It seems that this method is just to merge two steps in the first method into one step. However, the name of SVT is transparent to users if it is declared by One-step method.

Once SVT is declared, tokens can be tagged using %token, %left, %right or %nonassoc declaration to pick a member of SVT for them. And similarly nonterminals can be tagged using %type declarations to pick a member of SVT for them.

If a symbol is tagged, its semantic value can be referred to by pseudo-variables ($$, $1, $2 ...) in grammar actions. The pseudo-variable $$ stands for the semantic value for the nonterminal one of whose production is about to reduce to; $1 stands for the semantic value of the first symbol of the production; and $2 stands for the second, and so on.

For an untagged symbol, if its semantic value is referred to in grammar actions, then its semantic value have to be specified explicitly. The syntax is: insert a desired data member of SVT enclosed in ‘<’ and ‘>’ after ‘$’. For example, suppose SVT is declared in C++ as

%union%{

int nVal;

char *pszVal;

%}

If an untagged nonterminal at left side a production is treated as an integer, the pseudo-variable will be $<nVal>$. Similarly, if the first right side symbol of the production is treated as a string, the pseudo-variable will be $<pszVal>1.

This method is very useful for semantic value computation in middle rule actions. Comparing with ‘normal’ grammar actions at the end of right side of their associated productions, middle rule actions are embedded in productions. For each middle rule action, Upgen will replace the action with a new created nonterminal. This nonterminal has only a grammar rule whose production is empty and grammar action is the middle rule action. Since the nonterminal is auto-generated by Upgen, it cannot be declared.


SVT is typically implemented as a compound data structure in target language. In C++, it is often declared as a union with a list of data members who share the same memory in C++. In Object Pascal, it can be declared as a record which has variant parts so that the same data can be treated as belonging to different types, even in cases where compiler would not allow a typecast.


4.2.8 Location Structure

Every symbol has its location. Tracking symbols’ location is one of usual tasks of parsers, because it helps diagnose what the problem is and where the bugs may be whenever some errors are detected in the process of parsing. Location information is stored in a data structure called location structure.

If location structure declaration is absent, Upgen will generate a default version of it. The default location structure contains four integer members: firstLine, firstColumn, lastLine, lastColumn, which are called basic location information. In C++, it is defined as follows:

struct yyltype_t {

int firstLine;

int firstColumn;

int lastLine;

int lastColumn;

};

In Object Pascal, it looks like

yyltype_t = record

firstLine: integer;

firstColumn: integer;

lastLine: integer;

lastColumn: integer;

end;

In most cases, it is not necessary to declaration location structure declaration, for the default location structure is good enough for location tracking, unless extra information about location is needed. For user-defined location structure, be sure that it contains basic location information, for they are computed by the generated parser.

Like SVT, there are two ways to declare location structure: two-step method and one-step method.

  1. Two-step method

This method divides declaration into two steps: first declaring a data type in target language which contains at least basic location information; and then ‘assigning’ the data type to be location structure using a form of %location declaration. The syntax of the declaration is:

%location name-of-data-type-declared-in-target-language

For example, in C++, the default location structure can be declared as follows:

%{

struct mylocation_t {

int firstLine;

int firstColumn;

int lastLine;

int lastColumn;

};

%}

%location mylocation_t

  1. One-step method

The second method uses keyword %location followed by declaration body of user-defined location structure enclosed in ‘%{‘ and ‘%}’:

%union%{

declaration body of location structure in target language

%}

In last example, location structure can also be declared:

%location%{

int firstLine;

int firstColumn;

int lastLine;

int lastColumn;

%}

It seems that this method is just to merge two steps in the first method into one step. However, the name of location structure is transparent to users if it is declared by one-step method.

4.2.9 Destructors

Usually, allocating and freeing memory of symbols’ semantic value are handled in grammar actions. But there are many cases, where memory of some symbols may not be freed due to the parser discards them. During error recovery, symbols already pushed on the stack and tokens coming from the rest of the file are discarded until the parser falls on its feet. The other case is that the parser must discard start symbol even if it succeeds. To avoid the problem of memory leak, Upgen introduces destructors -- special actions which are executed whenever a symbol is discarded.

Clearly, the most typical operation of destructors is to free memory occupied by semantic value of discarded symbols allocated on heap.

All destructor declarations begin with keyword %destructor. There are four types of destructor declarations:

%destructor%{action-code-in-target-language%} a-list-of-symbols

%destructor%{action-code-in-target-language%} <a-member-of-SVT>

%destructor%{action-code-in-target-language%} <*>

%destructor%{action-code-in-target-language%} <>

Here, a-list-of-symbols are names of declared symbols separated by blanks (each of them is either a white-space or a tab). The first declaration is to associate a destructor with a list of symbols. That is, the destructor is executed whenever one of the symbols is discarded whose name appears in a-list-of-symbols. The second declaration is to associate a destructor with a member of semantic value type, which means the destructor is executed whenever a tagged symbol is discarded whose semantic value equals a-member-of-SVT. The third associates a destructor with all tagged symbols, which means the destructor is executed whenever a tagged symbol is discarded. And similarly, the last associates a destructor with all untagged symbols, which means the destructor is executed whenever an untagged symbol is discarded.

There may be conflicts if a symbol matches two or more destructors, when different types of destructor declarations are presented. The rule to resolve conflicts is to assign precedence to each type of destructor declaration, say, the first type has highest precedence, the second next to the first, etc; and then the destructor whose declaration has highest precedence among conflicts declarations is selected.

Two pseudo-variables are allowed to use in destructors except the ones of the fourth type: $$ and @$. The pseudo-variable $$ stands for semantic value of the symbol discarded; and @$ stands for location structure of the symbol discarded.

4.2.10 Special Actions

There are some special actions which are used to perform some certain tasks. The syntax of them is:

keyword%{

action-code-in-target-language

%}


Keyword is one of following keywords: %lex-init, %pre-match, %yywrap, %lvar-decl, %lexvar-decl, %lvar-init, %lexvar-init, %pvar-decl, %parsevar-decl, %pvar-init, %parsevar-init, %parse-init and %parse-exit.

In the body of these actions, no pseudo-variables are permitted.

  1. %lex-init action performs extra initialization before scanning a token. It is executed one time per token.

  2. %pre-match action performs extra tasks before any lexical action is executed.

  3. %yywrap action performs extra tasks of finalization before closing active buffer. It should be emphasized that a bool-valued must be returned from the action. If the value is false, execution of active <<EOF>> rule will be permitted; otherwise, the scanner will skip it and end its work.

  4. %lvar-decl (%lexvar-decl) action declares local variables for controlling function of scanners. This action is useful for programming languages such as Object Pascal, etc in which declarations of variables are separated from statements.

  5. %lvar-init (%lexvar-init) action initializes local variables for controlling function of scanners. The action is also provided for programming languages such as Object Pascal, etc in which declarations of variables are separated from statements. It is executed before scanning a token.

  6. %pvar-decl (%parsevar-decl) action declares local variables for controlling function of parsers. Like %lvar-decl, this action is useful for programming languages such as Object Pascal, etc in which declarations of variables are separated from statements.

  7. %pvar-init (%parsevar-init) action initializes local variables for controlling function of parser. Like %lvar-init, the action is provided for programming languages such as Object Pascal, etc in which declarations of variables are separated from statements. It is executed before parsing.

  8. %parse-init action performs extra tasks of initializing parser. It is executed before parsing,

  9. %parse-exit action performs extra tasks of finalizing parser. It is executed just before parser finished its job (whether or not it accepts input text).

These actions can be classified into two types:

  1. Lexical special action

The first five actions, that is, %lex-init action, %pre-match action, %yywrap action, %lvar-decl (%lexvar-decl) action, %lvar-init (%lexvar-init) are parts of the built-in scanner.

  1. Grammar special action

The last four actions, that is, %pvar-decl (%parsevar-decl) action, %pvar-init (%parsevar-init) action, %parse-init action, %parse-exit action are parts of the parser generated.

Obviously, lexical special actions are disabled when the built-in scanner is replaced by a user-defined scanner; grammar special actions are disabled when the parser is not available, cases in which grammar section is empty, or option -p is used.

4.3 Lexical Rules

The second section of script is lexical section. The form of this section is

Pattern-1 Action-1

Pattern-2 Action-2

...

A pattern and its associated lexical action form a lexical rule.

4.3.1 Patterns

Patterns accepted by Upgen are:

Pattern Comments

a match the character ‘a’

. any character except newline

[abc] a character class; in this case, the pattern matches either an ‘a’, a ‘b’, or a ‘c’

[a-fA-FZ] a character class with a range in it; matches a ‘Z’, any letter from ‘a’ through ‘f’, or from ‘A’ through ‘F’

[^ \t] a negated character class, that is, any character but those in the class; in this case, any character EXCEPT a white-space or a tab

[^ \t\n] any character EXCEPT a white-space, a tab or a newline

R* zero or more R’s, where R is any pattern

R+ one or more R’s

R? zero or one R’s (that is, an optional R)

R{2,5} anywhere from two to five R’s

R{2,} two or more R’s

R{4} exactly 4 R’s

R{,4} less than or equal to 4 R’s

{name} refers to pattern name

‘[abc]\”xyz’ the literal string: ‘[abc]”xyz’

\c if c is an ‘a’, ‘b’, ‘f’, ‘n’, ‘r’, ‘t’ or ‘v’, then escape character ‘\c’ in C++.

Otherwise, a literal ‘c’ (used to meta-characters such as ‘*’, ‘[’, ‘]’, etc)

\0 a NUL character (ASCII code 0)

\123 the character with octal value 123

\x2F the character with hexadecimal value 2F

(R) match an R; parentheses are used to override precedence

RS concatenation of the pattern R and the pattern S

R|S either an R or an S

R/S an R but only if it is followed by an S; the text matched by S is included when determining whether this rule is the longest match. Global variable yyleng indicates length of string matched by R, and yylaleng indicates length of string matched by RS.

^R an R, but only at the beginning of a line (for example, which just starting to scan, or right after a newline has been scanned)

R$ an R, but only at the end of a line; equivalent to R/\n. Note on some systems such as Windows a lexical rule is needed to filter out \r’s, or explicitly use R/\r\n for R$

<s>R an R, but only in start condition s

<s1,s2,s3> R same, but in any of start conditions s1, s2, or s3

<*>R an R in any start condition, even an exclusive one

<<EOF>> an end-of-file

<s1,s2><<EOF>> an end-of-file when in start condition s1 or s2


The patterns listed above are grouped according to precedence, from highest precedence at the top to lowest at the bottom. For example, a pattern for integers displayed on screen of calculators can be written as

0\.?|[\+\-]?[1-9][0-9]*\.?

is equivalent to

(0(\.)?)|((((([\+\-])?)([1-9]))(([0-9])*))((\.)?))

because the order of precedence is that ‘[]’ is highest, ‘*’ and ‘?’ next, then concatenation, and ‘|’ is the last.

Besides, there are built-in character classes presented by Upgen which are in common use in computer programming. They are

[:alnum:] [:alpha:] [:blank:]

[:cntrl:] [:digit:] [:graph:]

[:lower:] [:print:] [:punct:]

[:space:] [:upper:] [:xdigit:]

[:cidf:][:cids:]

The first twelve character classes all designate a set of characters equivalent to the corresponding standard C isXXXXX functions. For example, ‘[:blank:]’ designates characters for which C standard function isblank return true, say, a white-space or a tab; and ‘[:lower:]’ designates those characters for which C standard function islower returns true, say, any lowercase letter.

‘[:cidf:]’ represents legal first characters of identifiers in C language, while ‘[:cids:]’ stands for legal characters (except the first character) of identifiers in C language. Thus, the following characters are all equivalent:

[:cidf:]

[_A-Za-z]

_|[A-Z]|[a-z]

_|[:lower:]|[:upper:]

And ‘[:cids:]’ is equivalent to

[_0-9A-Za-z]

_|[0-9]|[A-Z]|[a-z]

_|[0-9]|[:lower:]|[:upper:]

When a pattern qualified with start conditions, it is active only when one of the start conditions is active. Using start conditions, same type of input text can be processed in different ways. For example, when Upgen is scanning grammar section, it treats comments (block comments ‘/* ... */’ and line comments ‘// ...’) in two ways. For such comments in grammar actions, they are copied to output verbatim. But for the ones outside of grammar actions, they are simply discarded quietly. Any start conditions have to be declared before they are available to use. To see declaration and usage of start conditions, see 4.2.3 Start Conditions.


There are some special kinds of patterns deserving more attention:

  1. Newline character

In Upgen, newline is a special character in following ways:

  1. A negated character class such as the example [^ \t] above will match a newline unless newline (‘\n’, ‘\x0a’ or other equivalent representation of newline) is one of the characters explicitly present in the negated character class (e.g., ‘[^ \t\n]’).

  2. When calling function yylexfile to initialize a scanner with interactive mode, scanning will be interrupted by newlines. For example, suppose following lexical rule is the only one lexical rule in lexical section:

\n+ ++match;

If the rule is fed with ten empty lines followed by ^d (end-of-file), then in interactive mode, the value of match will be 10; but in non-interactive mode, it will be 1. For the complete program, see example 4.3.1-1 in C++ and example 4.3.1-1 in Object Pascal.

For details on yylexfile, see Section 5.1.5 Interface Functions.

  1. On UNIX/LINUX, an empty line is ‘\n’; but On MS Windows, it will be ‘\r\n’. To make it more portable, it is better to design as ‘\r?\n’.


  1. Trailing context

A lexical rule can have at most one instance of trailing context operator (either ‘/’ or ‘$’).

There is a limitation for operator ‘/’. The patterns immediately after ‘/’ must be strings of fixed length. For example, following patterns are legal

abc/defg

“//”[^\n]*/\n

[0-9]+/[hHxXfF]

But

abc/defg*

”//”[^\n]*/\r?\n

[0-9]+/[hHxXfF]+

are all illegal. The reason is that before scanning, it is possible for the scanner to decide the length of strings which are matched by the pattern immediately after ‘/’ operator.


  1. Meta-characters

Following characters are meta-characters, when they appear in pattern name declarations or at unindented lines in lexical rule sections:

% ( ) [ ] { } < > | : $ ^ / * + , ; . ? - \

Meta-characters are a part of pattern syntax. They serve as either delimiters or operators. A way to express meta-character literally is to put a character ‘\’ in front of them or quoted them by single or double quotation marks so that they lose their syntactic meanings. The can also be represented by hexadecimal value or octal value of them. For example, question mark can be written in following ways

\?

‘?’

‘\?’

“?”

“\?”

\x3f

\079

Both single and double quotation marks are considered as meta-characters. As shown in above example, they make meta-characters lose their syntactic meanings. Quotation marks are not part of patterns, unless there is a character ‘\’ in front of them. Thus, ‘\’’ represents single quotation mark, and ‘\”’ double quotation mark. Like meta-characters, they can also be represented using hexadecimal value or octal value of them.


  1. <<EOF>>

<<EOF>> is a special pattern, which matches only at the time when end-of-file or a control character indicating the end of input from standard input is encountered, or end of string buffer is reached after reading the last character of the input buffer. The control character is ^d (ctrl + d) on UNIX/LINUX, ^z(ctrl + z) on MS Windows. But its associated action is executed only under the condition that the value returned from the special lexical action %yywrap is false. <<EOF>>’s do not work together with any other kinds of patterns except start conditions.

Usually, its associated action does one of following jobs, or combination of them:

  1. creating and switching a new input buffer,

  2. calling function yyterminate to end scanning,

  3. returning a token to parser,

  4. or other activities occasionally.


For example, following script counts abc’s in two ways

/* test user-defined END-OF-FILE action */

%{

#include <iostream>

using std::cout;

using std::endl;

%}


%x SC


%yywrap%{

switch(YYSTART()) {

case INITIAL:

cout << "scanner in start condition INITIAL." << endl;

break;

case SC: cout << "scanner in start condition SC." << endl;

break;

}

return false;

%}


%formal-param%{int &abcs %}

%actual-param%{ abcs %}

%%


abc ++abcs;


<SC>abc abcs += 10;


<<EOF>> yyrestart();

YYBEGIN(SC);


<SC><<EOF>> yyterminate();


<*>.|\n /* do nothing*/

%%

Start: /* empty */;

%%


int main(int argc, char **argv) {

if(yylexfile(argv[1], false)) return -1;


int abcs = 0;

yyparse(abcs);

cout << "abcs = " << abcs << endl;


return 0;

}

There are two <<EOF>> rules. The first is active only when start condition INITIAL is active. Its action is to force scanner to rescan the input file by calling yyrestart and activate start condition SC. And the second is active only when start condition SC is active. Its job is to terminate scanning by calling yyterminate. Thus, the task of the program is to scan input file twice, and counts one per abs’s occurrence at the first scan and ten per occurrence at the second scan. If the scanner is fed with a file which contains the text ‘abc’, the results will be

scanner in start condition INITIAL.

scanner in start condition SC.

abcs = 11

For the complete program, see example 4.3.1-2 in C++ and example 4.3.1-2 in Object Pascal.

4.3.2 Lexical Actions

Unlike other actions, lexical actions are not enclosed in ‘%{‘ and ‘%}’. To comply with LEX conventions, any indented lines (there are blanks in front of them) in lexical section are considered as a part of action associated with the pattern immediately before them. And blanks can only appear in character classes as a part of a pattern. This causes a little confusion. For example,

[ \t\n]

is considered a patter which is a character class represent a white-space or a tab or a newline; but

(abc \t\n)

is considered as a lexical rule, where (abc is interpreted a pattern (an illegal pattern, unfortunately), and \t\n) a part of an action associated the pattern (abc.


Whenever a pattern is selected to match input text, its associated (if any) action is executed. A pattern ends with (but excludes) a white-space, tab, newline or ‘|’. If a pattern does not end with ‘|’, the contents of the lexical action associated with the pattern will be the text between it and the next pattern. And if a pattern ends with ‘|’, the remained text in the same line of it is ignored and it shares lexical action of the next pattern. For example, lexical rules

abc Action-1

def Action-1

ghi Action-2

can be written as

abc |

def Action-1

ghi Action-2

as long as the action associated with pattern abc and the one associated with pattern def do exactly the same things.

When the input text is not matched by any patterns, error messages are emitted or default action is executed. If invocation of Upgen has option -S, default lexical rule is active to handle any unmatched input text. Otherwise, error message ‘Error: unmatched character’ is emitted, and scanner stops working.

The usual tasks of lexical actions are:

  1. Striping out comments and white-space, tab, newline characters

To strip out that text, you simply design patterns for them, and do nothing in their lexical actions.


  1. Recognizing tokens

The most important task of scanners is to recognize tokens, and compute attributes for them if necessary. Usually, the ID and attributes of the recognized token are passed to a parser. When the parser is enabled (that is, option -p is not present and grammar is not empty), there is a variable yylval for users to store attributes of the most recently recognized token and carry them to the parser. In fact, yylval is an instance of SVT, and serves as semantic value of look-ahead symbol. The value of yylval should always be initialized and updated in lexical actions (see Section 5.1.3 Interface Variables).


  1. Manipulating input buffers

Handling multiple input buffers is a normal task for a compiler. For example, C/C++ use #include directive to handle dependency between C/C++ files. The simple way to process such #include directive as #include <header-file> is to save the active input buffer, create a new input buffer for header-file, and activate it if it is available. When the input buffer for header-file is processed, the most recently active input buffer should be reactivated again.

In Upgen, an input buffer is an instance of YYPBUFFER. Every input buffer includes at least following information: interactive mode, line and column number of next character, size of tab character (‘\t’). Data members of input buffer should not be accessed directly. Instead, they should always be accessed through following interface functions:

  1. Functions dealing with interactive mode

yylexfile

yylexstr

yylexcstr

  1. Functions dealing with line and column number of next character

yyadd_lineno

yyadd_colno

yyget_lineno

yyget_colno

yyset_lineno

yyset_colno

yyinput

yyunput

yyunget

  1. Functions dealing size of tab character (‘\t’)

yyget_tabsize

yyset_tabsize


Input buffer manipulations include creating, switching, deleting, stack-pushing, stack-popping input buffer, etc. There are interface functions supported by Upgen to manipulate input buffers:

yy_current_buffer

yy_has_buffer

yy_push_buffer

yy_pop_buffer

yy_new_filebuf

yy_new_strbuf

yy_new_cstrbuf

yy_delete_buffer

yy_switch_buffer

All buffer manipulation functions can only be called in lexical actions and lexical special actions.

For details about lexical special actions, see Section 4.2.10 Special Actions.

For more interface functions, see Section 5.1.5 Interface Functions.


  1. Location tracking

Most time, Upgen takes care of location tracking of tokens as long as it is invoked with proper options. If invocation of Upgen with either option -l (enable only line number tracking) or -cl (enable both line and column number tracking) (see Chapter 1 Invocation), then there is a variable yylloc available for users to keep track of location information. The variable yylloc is an instance of location structure, and stores location information of the most recently recognized token which is passed to a parser to serve as location structure of look-ahead token. Like yylval, yylloc should only be used in lexical actions (see Section 5.1.3 Interface Variables).

Usually, yylloc is updated by the built-in scanner automatically just before a lexical action is executed. However, there are some interface functions provided by Upgen to change location of tokens. These functions are:

yyadd_lineno

yyadd_colno

yyget_lineno

yyset_lineno

yyget_colno

yyset_colno

yyget_tabsize

yyset_tabsize

In fact, these functions change location information of active input buffer, on which the computation of yylloc depends. For details about interface functions, see Section 5.1.5 Interface Functions

4.3.3 How the Input is Matched

In this section, the discussion will be around pattern matching algorithm. The first part of discussion is two strategies used by Upgen in the process of pattern matching, and the second is how some functions influence the behavior of pattern matching.

The two strategies are: greedy matching and first-pattern matching. Greedy matching means that when multiple patterns match some prefixes of input text, the only pattern will be selected that matches the longest prefix of input text. First-pattern matching is to resolve conflicts that there are still more than one patterns are chosen when strategy of greedy matching is applied to match input text. The solution is to choose the first pattern in order of appearance in script. For example, considering following four patterns

a

ab

abc

abc*

if these patterns are fed with text ‘abcc’, then the fourth pattern is chosen according to principle of greedy matching. But if the input text is ‘abc’, then the third pattern is chosen by principle of first-pattern matching. The principles apply to any patterns, including those which have trailing context operator (‘/’ and ‘$’ operators).

Following is implementation algorithm for pattern matching described in pseudo-code

textarea <- empty string

matched-text <- empty string

selected-pattern <- invalid pattern

repeat

c <- next character

append c to textarea

if textarea is matched perfectly then

matched-text <- textarea

selected-pattern <- first pattern that matches matched-text

until textarea is impossible matched by any patterns

put it back into the active input buffer the suffix of textarea such that concatenation of matched-text and it forms textarea

if selected-pattern is valid then

do its associated lexical action

else

if default lexical rule is active then

do default lexical action

else

emit error message of unmatched characters

As shown in the algorithm above, once a pattern is chosen to match input text, its associated lexical action is executed. In lexical actions, the variables yytext, yylaleng, yyleng are available to see the contents, the length of the whole text just matched and the length of the text matched before operator ‘/’ in the pattern (if any), respectively.


In lexical actions, there are some interface functions that can influence behavior of pattern matching. The list if all those interface functions is.

Start condition functions:

YYBEGIN

BEGIN

yy_push_state

yy_pop_state


BOL flag functions:

yy_set_bol


Input buffer functions:

yy_push_buffer

yy_pop_buffer

yy_delete_buffer

yy_switch_buffer

Miscellaneous functions:

yyrestart

yyterminate

yyinput

yyunput

yyunget

yymore

yyless


For details about interface functions, see Section 5.1.5 Interface Functions.

Function yy_set_bol , yyrestart, yymore and yyless deserves more attention.

Function yy_set_bol sets BOL flag (beginning of line) of active input buffer. It is often invoked after a serial of yyinput’s or an yyrestart to adjust the value of BOL flag for next character. For example, considering following lexical rules

"//" int c = yyinput();

while(c != '\n' && c != END_OF_FILE)

c = yyinput();

yy_set_bol(true);

^abc cout << "abc at BOL." << endl;

abc cout << "abc at other position." << endl;

.|\n

if following text is entered

//this is a sample to test yy_set_bol

abcdabc

then the results will be

abc at BOL.

abc at other position.

(see example 4.3.3-1 in C++ and example 4.3.3-1 in Object Pascal). But if the first rule does not call yy_set_bol(true), the output will be:

abc at other position.

abc at other position.

(see example 4.3.3-2 in C++ and example 4.3.3-2 in Object Pascal).


Function yyrestart forces scanners to rescan active input buffer from the beginning of it. The active input buffer here is assumed to be random-access stream.

CAUTION: Be careful not to use yyrestart unconditionally, or the scanner will run into endless loop.

Following example will demonstrate how to use yyrestart.

/* built-in function: yyrestart() */

%{

#include <iostream>

using std::cout;

using std::endl;

%}


%formal-param%{ int &rstimes, int &ncnt %}

%actual-param%{ rstimes, ncnt %}

%%


^good! ++ncnt;

cout << yytext << "[" << ncnt << "]" << endl;


<<EOF>> if(rstimes < 3) {

++rstimes;

yyrestart();

yy_set_bol(true);

}

.|\n

%%

%%

int main(int argc, char **argv) {

int rstimes = 0, ncnt = 0;

yylexfile(argv[1], false);

yylex(rstimes, ncnt);

cout << endl << "good!\'s occurrences: " << ncnt << endl;


return 0;

}

If the scanner is fed with a file whose contents is ‘good!’, then the output will be

good![1]

good![2]

good![3]

good![4]


good!'s occurrences: 4

(see example 4.3.3-3 in C++ and example 4.3.3-3 in Object Pascal).


Function yymore makes next matched text append to current matched text rather than replace it. For example, consider following lexical rules

hello\, YYECHO(); yymore();

world! YYECHO();

if the input text is ‘hello,world!’, then the output will be

hello,

hello,world!

Function YYECHO is the same as ECHO, which simply prints yytext on standard output. Since yymore has an effect on yytext and yyleng, it is always recommended that yymore should be called at the end of lexical actions, or there may be some undesired results.

There is an even more advanced example involving yymore and trailing context operator ‘/’. Considering following lexical rules

Hello\,\040/world\! {

cout << "whole-text = " << yytext << endl;

cout << "lookahead-text = " << &yytext[yyleng] << endl;

yytext[yyleng] = '\0';

cout << "matched-text = " << yytext << endl;

yymore();

}

world\! {

cout << "whole-text = " << yytext << endl;

cout << "lookahead-text = " << &yytext[yyleng] << endl;

yytext[yyleng] = '\0';

cout << "matched-text = " << yytext << endl;

}

if input text is ‘Hello, world!’, the result will be

whole-text = Hello, world!

lookahead-text = world!

matched-text = Hello,

whole-text = Hello, world!

lookahead-text =

matched-text = Hello, world!

(see example 4.3.3-4 in C++ and example 4.3.3-4 in Object Pascal).


Function yyless(n) returns yyleng – n characters to active input buffer, and causes them to be rescanned.

CAUTION: the argument n should always be greater than zero, or scanner will be trapped into endless loop.

Like yymore, it should be called at the end of lexical actions. For example,

"hello, world!" cout << yytext << endl; yyless(7);

"world!" cout << yytext << endl;

If the contents of input text is ‘hello, world!’, the output will be

hello, world!

world!

Next example involves yyless and operator ‘/’.

hello\,my/\x20world\! {

cout << "whole-text = " << yytext << endl;

cout << "lookahead-text = " << &yytext[yyleng] << endl;

yytext[yyleng] = '\0';

cout << "matched-text = " << yytext << endl;

yyless(6);

}

my\x20world\! {

cout << "whole-text = " << yytext << endl;

cout << "lookahead-text = " << &yytext[yyleng] << endl;

yytext[yyleng] = '\0';

cout << "matched-text = " << yytext << endl;

}

Feeding these two lexical rules with text ‘hello,my world!’, the output will be

whole-text = hello,my world!

lookahead-text = world!

matched-text = hello,my

whole-text = my world!

lookahead-text =

matched-text = my world!

For the complete program, see example 4.3.3-5 in C++ and example 4.3.3-5 in Object Pascal.

4.3.4 Lexical Special Actions

There are five types of lexical special actions: %lex-init action, %pre-match action, %yywrap action, %lvar-decl (%lexvar-decl) action, %lvar-init (%lexvar-init). For details on them, see section 4.2.10 Special Actions.

4.4 Grammar Rules

The third section of a script is grammar section. A grammar rule consists of a production and an optional grammar action at right end of its associated production. A production has the following general form:

A: X1X2X3...

where A is left side nonterminal, X1, X2, X3 are right side symbols, each of them is either a token or a nonterminal.

And the general form of a grammar rule is:

Production %{ Grammar-action-code-in-target-language %}

;

where Production is a production in general form, and Grammar-action-code-in-target-language is a block of code in target language. If left side nonterminal A has at least two rules, then these rules are written in the following form, where a Rule is a grammar rule in general form without A and colon:

A: Rule 1

| Rule 2

| ...

| Rule N

;

4.4.1 Productions

As mentioned above, a production includes a nonterminal at its left side, a sequence of symbols at its right side and a colon between both sides. In this section, the discussion focuses on some issues related to productions.


4.4.1.1 Empty Productions

The right side of a production can be empty, which means the nonterminal at left side matches empty string of tokens. For example, the grammar of the right side of a production in general form can be defined:

Production_Items: /* empty */

| Production_Items Production_Item

;

Production_Item: TOKEN

| NONTERMINAL

;

Conventionally, comments /* empty */ is added for empty productions.


4.4.1.2 Middle Rule Actions

There may be some grammar actions embedded in a production, which are called middle rule actions. For such a production with middle rule actions, Upgen will replace each middle rule action with a new created nonterminal with only one grammar rule which has an empty production and the middle rule action as its grammar action. This way, all productions are normalized into general form. For example, following grammar rule is supposed to generate code for loop statement for a certain language:

Loop_Statement: Loop %{

$<Label>$ = NewLabel(); //create a label

%}

Statements EndLoop %{

Emit(“Jump “ + $<Label>2) ; // generate a unconditional jump

%};

It will be normalized as

Loop_Statement: Loop @@1 Statements EndLoop %{

Emit(“Jump “ + $<Label>2) ; // generate a unconditional jump

%};

@@1: %{

$<Label>$ = NewLabel(); //create a label

%};

The nonterminal @@1 is generated by Upgen, substituting for middle rule action in the original grammar rule. As shown in above grammar rules, both $<Label>$ in middle rule action and $<Label>2 in the action at the end of production represent semantic value of the middle rule action (@@1, to be exact).


4.4.1.3 Left-recursive

Left-recursive production has the form that the nonterminal on the left side is also the first component of right side. For example, following productions are left-recursive, which intend to analyze argument list separated by commas:

Arguments: Argument // rule 1

| Arguments ‘,’ Argument // rule 2

;

By comparison, right-recursive form of them is

Arguments: Argument // rule 1

| Argument ‘,’ Arguments //rule 2

;

In LR grammars, left-recursive is almost always better than right-recursive, as inferred from following example. This example will show you details about the process of parsing an argument list using both left-recursive and right-recursive productions in the previous grammar. Suppose there is an argument list:

a1 , a2 , a3 , a4

to be parsed. For left-recursive, the sequence of shift/reduce actions is

Configuration (stack* input) Actions

01 *a1 , a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘a1’

02 Argument* , a2 , a3 , a4 reduce by rule1

03 Arguments* , a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘,’

04 Arguments ,* a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘a2’

05 Arguments , Argument* , a3 , a4 reduce by rule 2

06 Arguments * , a3 , a4 shift ‘,’

07 Arguments ,* a3 , a4 shift ‘a3’

08 Arguments , Argument* , a4 reduce by rule 2

09 Arguments* , a4 shift ‘,’

10 Arguments ,* a4 shift ‘a4’

11 Arguments , Argument* reduce by rule 2

12 Arguments*

The asterisk ‘*’ indicates the position of the top element of parsing stack; that is, contents of parsing stack is on the left side of the asterisk and input text unparsed on the right side. For the configuration

Argument* , a2 , a3 , a4

only an nonterminal Argument is on the stack and the text ‘, a2 , a3 , a4’ remains unparsed.

Now, turning to right-recursive version, the sequence of shift/reduce actions will be

Configuration (stack* input) Actions

01 *a1 , a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘a1’

02 Argument* , a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘,’

03 Argument ,* a2 , a3 , a4 shift ‘a2’

04 Argument , Argument* , a3 , a4 shift ‘,’

05 Argument , Argument ,* a3 , a4 shift ‘a3’

06 Argument , Argument , Argument* , a4 shift ‘,’

07 Argument , Argument , Argument ,* a4 shift ‘a4’

08 Argument , Argument , Argument ,Argument* reduce by rule 1

09 Argument , Argument , Argument ,Arguments* reduce by rule 2

10 Argument , Argument , Arguments* reduce by rule 2

11 Argument , Arguments* reduce by rule 2

12 Arguments*


As shown in the two versions of configurations above, in left-recursive version, the number of elements on parsing stack is at most three; but in right-recursive version, this number is a linear function of the number of arguments entered, which may cause serious problems for the program in which space is at a premium. In fact, for LR (k) grammars left-recursive almost always defeats right-recursive in space efficiency.


4.4.1.4 Useless Symbols

Upgen preprocesses grammar rules before it translates them into target program. One of jobs of preprocessing is to detect and eliminate useless symbols. There are two types of useless symbols: nonterminals that are not generating and symbols that are not reachable. For example, suppose there is a grammar that looks like:

%token NUM

%start SText

%%

.

%%

SText: /* empty */

| SText Expr ‘\n’

;

Expr: Expr ‘+’ Expr

| Expr ‘-‘ Expr

| ‘(‘ Expr ‘)’

;

Term: NUM;

%%

The nonterminal Expr is a useless nonterminal of the first type, because it cannot generate any sequence of tokens. The symbols Term and NUM are all useless nonterminal of the second type, since the start symbol SText cannot generate any sequence of symbols containing Term or NUM.

The scheme of useless symbol elimination is: first eliminate useless symbols of the first type, and then eliminate useless symbols of the second type from the remaining grammar rules. After the elimination of useless symbols only useful symbols are left. And it has been proven that eliminating useless symbols will not change the language generated. For the example above, the equivalent grammar after the elimination of useless symbols is the one that can only accept empty text with only one empty production:

SText: /* empty */

;

If there are some useless symbols in a grammar, warning messages will be emitted by Upgen. The warning messages for the previous grammar are:

Warning: following symbols never referred

NUM '+' '-' '('

')' Expr Term

Warning: following grammar rules never referred

3 SText : SText Expr '\n'

4 Expr : Expr '+' Expr

5 Expr : Expr '-' Expr

6 Expr : '(' Expr ')'

7 Term : NUM


The details about preprocessed grammar can be found in the ‘.detailed’ file, which is generated by Upgen if it is invoked with option –v. For the previous grammar, the contents of ‘.detailed’ file are:

---------------------- Grammar --------------------------------

Accept-symbol: $accept

Start-symbol: SText

Terminals:

0 $end ($untagged) 1 $error ($untagged)

2 $undefined ($untagged) 3 '\n' ($untagged)

Variables:

4 SText ($untagged) 5 $accept ($untagged)

Productions:

0 $accept: SText $end

1 SText:


---------------------- LALR Items -----------------------------

Number of states: 3

State 1

0 $accept: . SText $end

1 SText:

goto action

SText ----> state 2

reduce action

($default), reduce to [SText] by rule 1

State 2

0 $accept: SText . $end

shift action

$end ----> state 3

State 3

0 $accept: SText $end .

reduce action

($default), reduce to [$accept] by rule 0

This file contains two sections: the first section contains four elements of the grammar, say, start symbol, terminals, nonterminals and productions; the second section contains LALR (1) automaton that recognizes the language of the grammar.

4.4.2 Grammar Actions

Once a production is chosen to apply to a sequence of tokens (that is, a reduce action is taken), its associated grammar action will be invoked, if any. Grammar actions consist of statements in target language. And their most typical task is to compute semantic value of symbols and produce some output.

4.4.2.1 Semantic Value Computation

One of main jobs of grammar actions is to compute semantic values. In Upgen, all the semantic value computation is based on the parsing stack. Whenever a grammar action is about to be executed the pseudo-variables $1, $2 ... (semantic value of right side symbols of its associated production) are already computed and placed on the top of the parsing stack. Only the pseudo-variable $$ (semantic value of left side of its associated production) remains unknown. Hence, from the point of view of semantic value computation, grammar actions act like mathematic functions whose independent variables are $1, $2 ... and the dependent variable is $$, which can be written in the form:

$$: f ($1, $2...)

After $$ is computed, $1, $2 ... will be thrown away, and then $$ will be placed at the top of parsing stack, which becomes $n (n may be 1 or 2 or else number) during another execution of a grammar action subsequently.

For example, following two grammar rules are excerpted from idc1.upg that describes an expression as either a number or the sum of two other expressions:

Expr: NUM %{ $$ = $1; %} // rule 1

| Expr ‘+’ Expr %{ $$ = $1 + $3; %} // rule 2

;

And suppose the input text is

3 + 5

The following figure illustrates how semantic values are computed by presenting the sequence of configurations of parsing stack.

Parsing stack $$’s value Description

# NA ready to parse

# $1:3 NA after shifting ‘3’

# $1:3 ? before executing action 1

# $1:3 3 executing action 1

# $1:3 NA after executing action 1, pop $1, push $$

# $1:3 $2:+ NA after shifting ‘+’

# $1:3 $2:+ $1:5 NA after shifting ‘5’

# $1:3 $2:+ $1:5 ? before executing action 1

# $1:3 $2:+ $1:5 5 executing action 1

# $1:3 $2:+ $1:5 NA after executing action 1, pop $1, push $$

# $1:3 $2:+ $3:5 ? before executing action 2

# $1:3 $2:+ $3:5 8 executing action 2

# $1:8 NA after executing action 2, pop $3 $2 $1, push $$

In the figure above, ‘#’ indicates bottom of parsing stack; ‘?’ means the value of the pseudo-variable is undefined; ‘NA’ means the pseudo-variable is not accessible; and each item on the parsing stack has the form:

$n:value

For example, item ‘$2: +’ means the value of $2 is ‘+’.

The above example is quite simple, but more powerful parsers made by Upgen follow the same logic.

4.4.2.2 Location Tracking

Upgen takes care of computation of basic location information of all symbols if it is invoked with proper options to make the parser (see Chapter 1 Invocation and Section 4.3.2 Lexical Actions -> Location Tracking). Scanners and parsers generated by Upgen play different roles in location tracking. Scanners are responsible for tracking location of all tokens, and parsers for tracking location of all nonterminals. With assumption that tokens’ locations are already computed by scanners, this section only explains how nonterminals’ locations are computed.

Like semantic values, in grammar actions the pseudo-variables @$ refers to location of the nonterminal at left side of their associated productions, and @1, @2 ... refer to locations of the first, the second ... symbols at right side of their associated productions respectively. In fact, symbols’ locations are computed in the same way as semantic values’. Upgen provides a stack for location computation which is called location stack. And all the location computation is also based on location stack. The only difference between location computation and semantic value computation is that basic location information of @$ is computed automatically (by parsers), while $$ is computed manually (by semantic rules). For a nonempty production A: X1X2...Xn, Upgen uses following algorithm to compute basic location information of @$:

@$.firstLine <- @1.firstLine

@$.firstColumn <- @1.firstColumn

@$.lastLine <- @n.lastLine

@$.lastColumn <- @n.lastColumn

For an empty production A: /* empty */, the method will be:

@$.firstLine <- @0.lastLine

@$.firstColumn <- @0.lasstColumn

@$.lastLine <- @0.lastLine

@$.lastColumn <- @0.lastColumn

(Note: @0 refers to the topmost element of location stack)

However, there are parser programs that need to track extra information about locations. To track extra location information, the default location structure should be replaced with user-defined location structure, which is declared by %location declaration (see Section 4.2.8 Location Structure). The user-defined location structure must include basic location information and some extra data members to be tracked. For the extra members of location structure, their computation is the exact same as semantic values’.

4.4.2.3 Accept or Reject

From the point of view of formal languages, parsing is in fact a membership test of a language. If a string belongs to a language, the parser, which is a program used to recognize the language, will accept the string. Otherwise, it will reject the string. In Upgen, whether the parser accepts or rejects the string is indicated by the value returned by the controlling function yyparse of the parser: accepts if the value is zero; rejects otherwise.

Usually, parsing process will continue until the parser encounters the end of input or an unrecoverable error. If no error is encountered, the controlling function yyparse will return zero; otherwise, it will return a non-zero error code. But there are still some applications in which the to-be-parsed string is only a part of input text, and the acceptance may be declared (calling YYACCEPT) at any desired point of the processing.

When a parser encounters an unrecoverable syntax error, it emits error messages and aborts its execution with non-zero error code returned. But for semantic errors, it may emit warning or error messages, or force to abort parsing by calling interface function YYABORT if the error is serious.

4.4.2.4 Grammar Special Actions

There are four types of grammar special actions: %pvar-decl (%parsevar-decl) action, %pvar-init (%parsevar-init) action, %parse-init action, %parse-exit action. For details on them, see section 4.2.10 Special Actions.

4.4.3 Resolve Conflicts for Ambiguous Grammars

How to deal with ambiguity in grammars is one of most common issues for grammar design. If a grammar is ambiguous, some strings of the language of the grammar may be parsed in different ways. Put it another way, ambiguity in a grammar may introduce certain amount of uncertainty and complexness. For some grammars, it is possible to redesign them to make them unambiguous. But unfortunately, there are grammars that always remain ambiguous, which are called inherently ambiguous grammars.

In fact, there are ambiguous grammars in previous chapters. For example, the grammar in idc1.upg is ambiguous, because there are different ways to construct nonterminal Expr. Consider the following productions excerpting from idc1.upg:

Expr: NUM // rule 1

| Expr ‘+’ Expr // rule 2

;

Suppose the input text is

1 + 2 + 3

The sequence of shift/reduce actions can be

Configuration (stack* input) Actions

01 *1 + 2 + 3 shift ‘1’

02 NUM* + 2 + 3 reduce by rule 1

03 Expr* + 2 + 3 shift ‘+’

04 Expr +* 2 + 3 shift ‘2’

05 Expr + NUM* + 3 reduce by rule 1

06 Expr + Expr* + 3 reduce by rule 2

07 Expr* + 3 shift ‘+’

08 Expr +* 3 shift ‘3’

09 Expr + NUM* reduce by rule 1

10 Expr + Expr* reduce by rule 2

11 Expr*

Or

Configuration (stack* input) Actions

01 *1 + 2 + 3 shift ‘1’

02 NUM* + 2 + 3 reduce by rule 1

03 Expr* + 2 + 3 shift ‘+’

04 Expr +* 2 + 3 shift ‘2’

05 Expr + NUM* + 3 reduce by rule 1

06 Expr + Expr* + 3 shift ‘+’

07 Expr + Expr +* 3 shift ‘3’

08 Expr + Expr + NUM* reduce by rule 1

09 Expr + Expr + Expr* reduce by rule 2

10 Expr + Expr* reduce by rule 2

11 Expr*

Comparing the two configurations above, the differences begin at line 06: the parser performs a shift action in configuration 1 but a reduce action by rule 1 in configuration 2.

The conflict of whether the parser should take a shift action or a reduce action is called shift/reduce conflict. There are two different methods to resolve shift/reduce conflicts: redesign grammar or make choice between shifts and reduces. As an example, both methods are employed to remove ambiguity in the grammar of idc1.upg.

For first method, the ambiguity in the grammar is removed by redesigning the part of the grammar that constructs Expr. Its updated version is:

Expr: Term // rule 1

| Expr ‘+’ Term // rule 2

;

Term: NUM // rule 3

| ‘(‘ Expr ‘)’ // rule 4

;

Testing the grammar with input text ‘1 + 2 + 3’, there is only one configuration remained:

Configuration (stack* input) Actions

01 *1 + 2 + 3 shift ‘1’

02 NUM* + 2 + 3 reduce by rule 3

03 Term* + 2 + 3 reduce by rule 1

04 Expr* + 2 + 3 shift ‘+’

05 Expr +* 2 + 3 shift ‘2’

06 Expr + NUM* + 3 reduce by rule 3

07 Expr + Term* + 3 reduce by rule 2

08 Expr* + 3 shift ‘+’

09 Expr +* 3 shift ‘3’

10 Expr + NUM* reduce by rule 3

11 Expr + Term* reduce by rule 2

12 Expr*

Now for second method, the parser always chooses reduce action whenever a shift/reduce conflict occurs, because following mathematic conventions, addition operator is left-associative. The following declaration will tell the parser that ‘+’ is a left-associative operator:

%left ‘+’

For grammars with multiple operators which are source of shift/reduce conflicts, it is often necessary to specify not only operators’ associativity but also their precedence. For syntax of declaring operators’ associativity and precedence, see section 4.2.4 Grammar Symbols.

Ambiguity in grammars may cause another type of conflicts: reduce/reduce conflicts, which occurs if there are multiple rules that apply to the same sequence of input text. For example, following grammar is to recognize ‘language’ of parentheses:

Expr: /* empty */

| '(' Expr ')'

Expr Expr

;

There are reduce/reduce conflicts in this grammar, because even for empty string, there are different sequences of reductions to be chosen to parse it. The best way to resolve reduce/reduce conflicts is to redesign the grammar if it is possible. For the grammar above, reduce/reduce conflicts can be resolved by introducing another nonterminal. The updated grammar looks like

Lang: /* empty */

| Expr

;

Expr: ‘(‘ ‘)’

| ‘(‘ Expr ‘)’

| Expr Expr

;

Sometimes, reduce/reduce conflicts are tough to be resolved. And sometimes, techniques to resolve conflicts involve extra work of the scanner. For such special techniques, see Section 4.5 Interaction between Scanner and Parser.

If reduce/reduce conflicts remain unresolved, Upgen always choose the first rule according to the order of appearance.

4.4.4 Error Recovery

It is not unusual for parser programs to encounter errors in the process of parsing. There are three categories of errors in parser programs made by Upgen: lexical errors, syntax errors and semantic errors. For lexical errors, the major issue is how to deal with illegal strings of characters. There are two methods for a scanner to handle those illegal strings of characters: ignores them with emitting warning/error messages; or treats them as syntax errors by returning invalid tokens to the parser. And for semantic errors, heuristic methods are often used because there are not unanimous strategies to handle them.

And for syntax errors, Upgen provides a tool to recover from them. This tool is error recovery rules which consists an error production and its associated grammar action.

Error productions are those productions containing keyword error that only serve purpose of error recovery. The most typical form of error production is:

Nonterminal: error sequence-of-symbols

The first step to design error productions is to figure out what ‘major’ nonterminals will have error recovery rules associated them. Typical choices are those which generate expressions, statements, blocks and procedures. For example, as shown in Section 3.1.6 Step 4: Simple Error Recovery, the nonterminal Line is chosen to be the ‘major’ nonterminal, and its associated error production is as follows:

Line: ‘\n’

| Expr ‘\n’

| error ‘\n’

;

The third production of Line is an error production.

In Upgen, error productions are treated as ordinary productions; and error is treated as normal untagged token. The only difference is that token error is not from input text. When a token recognized by the scanner is not what the parser wants, the parser enters error recovery mode. In error recovery mode, the parser pops symbols from parsing stack until token error can be shifted onto parsing stack; and then it discards input tokens until it finds a token on which normal parsing can proceed. Often, the grammar actions associated error productions call function yyerrok to tell the parser return back to normal mode.

Another issue may arise from error recovery: free memory occupied by discarded symbols. For the symbols whose memory is allocated on heap, declaration destructors should be declared for them to free their memory before the parser discards them during error recovery.

4.5 Interaction between Scanner and Parser

Upgen takes lexical and grammar description of a language and makes both the scanner and the parser for it. The scanner, which is designed to be hidden from users, is invoked by the parser implicitly. Hence it is not necessary to worry about how, where and when the parser calls the scanner since Upgen takes care of interaction between them.

It is natural to view the interaction as one-way relation, because most time the scanner recognizes tokens in its own way, quite independent from the parser. But there are still some programs which need two-way interaction to help resolving some conflicts. They require that the scanner’s behavior should be affected by its context, so that some strings of characters may be recognized in different ways. Following example demonstrate a way to implement two-way interaction between the scanner and the parser.

Suppose there is an extensible LISP-like calculator that supports user-defined functions. Its syntax borrows from LISP. Lexical and grammar rules of it are designed as follows:

...

%token DEF NUM CID ARG FUNC

...

%% /* lexical rules followed */

...

[:cidf:][:cids:]* if(processing_expr) {

// identifier in expression

// it refers to either an argument or a function

if(find_arg(yytext))

return ARG;

else if(find_func(yytext))

return FUNC;

return -1; // illegal identifier,

}

return CID; // the identifier is argument name or function name

...

%% /* grammar rules followed */

...

Blck: Expr ‘;’

| ‘(‘ DEF %{

processing_expr = false;

%}

CID ‘(‘ Args ‘)’ %{

processing_expr = true;

%}

Expr ‘)’ ‘;’

;

Args: /* empty */

| CID Args

;

Expr: NUM

| ARG

| ‘(‘ Optr Exprs ‘)’

| ‘(‘ FUNC Exprs ‘)’

;

Optr: ‘+’ | ‘-‘ | ‘*’ | ‘/’

;

Exprs: Expr

| Expr Exprs

;

%% /* user code followed */

...


As shown in the script above, the pattern '[:cidf:][:cids:]*' matches strings that represent one of three different types of tokens: token CID (name of user-defined function or formal argument), token ARG (actual argument) or token FUNC (invocation of user-defined function). How the scanner interprets those strings depends on the variable processing_expr, whose value is changed by following grammar rule:

Blck: ‘(‘ DEF %{

processing_expr = false;

%}

CID ‘(‘ Args ‘)’ %{

processing_expr = true;

%}

Expr ‘)’ ‘;’

;

In this way the scanner’s behavior are influenced by the parser. For more details about this example, see Section 6.2 A Complete Example.

.

4.6 Multiple Parsers in the Same Program

Although most programs that use Upgen need a single parser to analyze only one language, there are some programs that require multiple parsers. In such programs, there is a potential problem of name conflicts among different definitions of interfaces to the parsers, such as yyparse/yylex, yylval, yylloc, etc. The solution to the problem is option -P, which specifies name prefix of some interfaces to the generated parser. If invocation of Upgen has not option -P, the default name prefix ‘yy’ is applied to those interfaces. Following interfaces (with default name prefix ‘yy’) are influenced by option -P:

Data types:

yylex_t

yyerror_t

Variables:

yylval

yylloc

Functions:

yysetstream

yyseterror

yysetlex

yyclearall

yylexfile

yylexstr

yylexcstr

yylex

yyparse

Taking idc1.upg as and example, if name prefix is changed into ‘zz’, then script of idc1.upg has to be updated as follows:

...

%% /* lexical rules and actions follow */

[0-9]+ zzlval.nVal = atoi(yytext);

return NUM;

...

%% /* grammar rules and actions follow */

...

%% /* user code follow */


int main(int argc, char **argv) {

if(zzlexfile(NULL, true)) {

cerr << “Error: initialization failed.” << endl;

return -1;

}


return zzparse();

}

Here, yylval, yylexfile, yyparse are changed into zzlval, zzlexfile, zzparse respectively. The command to make the parser must include option –P zz, as shown in following line:

$ upgen -P zz –o idc1.cpp idc1.upg


5 Interfaces in Target Language

Interfaces to the parser generated by Upgen include a set of data types, constants, variables (including pseudo-variables) and functions in form of target language. Using these interfaces, the user can interact with the parser and change its behaviors if necessary.

This chapter will show you details about all the interfaces. In section 5.1, the general description of all interfaces is given in the form of table. And in section 5.2 and 5.3, interface functions are presented with assumption that the target language will be C++ and Object Pascal, respectively.

5.1 General Description of Interfaces

In Upgen, interfaces can be classified according to two criteria. The first criterion is “where can they be used”; and the second is “with/without what options are they enabled”. Interfaces are divided into three types according to the first criterion: interfaces which can be used only in lexical actions, only in grammar actions and outside of them. And according to the second criterion, they can also be divided into types: interfaces which are enabled with option -l, without option -m or without option -p.

Following table presents details of interfaces. For the sake of convenience, following conventions are used in the table:

  1. In column 2, ‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’ stand for interfaces which can be used only in lexical actions, only in grammar actions, and outside of them, respectively. ‘ABC’, for example, stands for interfaces can be used anywhere; and ‘AB’ stands for interfaces can be used in both lexical actions and grammar actions.

  2. In column 3, ‘-’ and ‘+’ stand for ‘without option ...’ and ‘with options ...’, respectively. Thus ‘-m’ means interfaces enabled only without option -m; and ‘+l’ stands for interfaces enabled only with option -l. Besides, “None” stands for interfaces which are always available no matter what options are present or absent.


Name

Criterion 1

Criterion 2

Comments

5.1.1 Data types

yyerror_t

C

None

Pointer-to-procedure type; its signature is the same as yyerror; and in fact, yyerror is an instance of yyerror_t. yyerror can be replaced by a user-defined error report routine of yyerror_t type by calling yyseterror.

yylex_t

C

-p

Pointer-to-function type; its signature is the same as yylex; and in fact, yylex is an instance of yylex_t, and can be replaced by a user-defined scanning function of yylex_t type by calling yysetlex, which means all lexical rules and lexical special actions are never executed.

YYPBUFFER

ABC

-m

Input buffer type.

Instances of it are returned by yy_current_buffer, yy_new_filebuf, yy_new_cstrbuf and yy_new_strbuf. Its instances can be pushed down into and popped from input buffer stack by calling yy_push_buffer, yy_pop_buffer respectively. By calling yy_switch_buffer, an instance of it becomes active. To delete active input buffer, call yy_delete_buffer.

5.1.2 Constants

END_OF_FILE

ABC

None

A constant stands for end of file.

If the value returned by yyinput is equal to END_OF_FILE, end of file is reached for active input buffer.

PAS_EOF (only for Object Pascal)

ABC

None

Equals ctrl + z, (ASCII code is 26)

5.1.3 Variables

yylval

A

-p

Semantic value of look-ahead token.

It is an instance of SVT. One of main jobs of lexical actions is to compute the value of yylval.

Do not use it in any other places except lexical actions.

yylloc

A

-p

Location of look-ahead token.

It is an instance of location structure. Basic location information of it is computed automatically if proper options (with option -l, without options -m or –p) are present. With option -m, its value is computed manually; and with option -p or without -l, it is not available for users. Usually, only extra members of yylloc need to be computed, if any.

Do not use it in any other places except lexical actions.

5.1.4 Pseudo-variables

$$, $1, ...

B

-p

Semantic value of symbols.

For a grammar action at the end of its associated production such as A: X1X2X3... in which A is left side nonterminal to be constructed, X1, X2, X3 are right side symbols (each of them is a token, a nonterminal, or a middle rule action), any $$ represents semantic value of A, $1, $2, $3, ... represent semantic value of X1, X2, X3, ... respectively. Inside middle rule actions, use $<...>$ instead of $$, since the nonterminal representing the action cannot be tagged.

Do not use these pseudo-variables in any other places except grammar actions.

@$, @1, ...

B

+l –p

Location of symbols.

For a grammar action at the end of its associated production such as A: X1X2X3... in which A is left side nonterminal to be constructed, X1, X2, X3 are right side symbols (each of them is a token, a nonterminal, or a middle rule action), any @$ represents location of A, @1, @2, @3, ... represent location of X1, X2, X3, ... respectively. With proper options (with option -l, without options -m or –p), basic location information of all symbols are computed automatically. With option -m, its value is computed manually; and with option -p or without -l, it is not available for users. In any grammar actions, only @1, @2 ... can be referred to, because the value of @$ is undefined yet at that point.

Do not use them in any other places except grammar actions

$<...>$, $<....>1, ...

B

-p

Semantic value of symbols.

The text enclosed in ‘<’ and ‘>’ is semantic value.

They are almost as the same as $$, $1 ... with exception of the case of untagged symbols or forcing tagged symbols to be other type of semantic value.

5.1.5 Functions

YYECHO()

A

-m

Output the text that is contained in yytext to the output stream specified by yysetstream.

ECHO()

A

-m

Same as YYECHO.

YYBEGIN(sc)

A

-m

Activate start condition sc.

BEGIN(sc)

A

-m

Same as YYBEGIN, only available for languages such that BEGIN is not reserved word.

YYSTART()

A

-m

Return active start condition.

yy_push_state(sc)

A

-m

Push down current active start condition onto start condition stack and activate start condition sc.

yy_pop_state()

A

-m

Pop up the start condition at the top of start condition stack and activate it

yy_top_state()

A

-m

Return start condition at the top of start condition stack; it has no side effect.

yy_get_bol()

A

-m

Return BOL (beginning of a line) flag of active input buffer; it has no side effect.

yy_set_bol(b)

A

-m

Set BOL (beginning of a line) flag of active input buffer. If b is true, then next character is considered as the character at the beginning of a line.

yy_current_buffer()

A

-m

Return active input buffer.

yy_has_buffer()

A

-m

Decide if there is an input buffer need to process

yy_push_buffer(pbuf)

A

-m

Push down input buffer pbuf onto buffer stack and activate it.

yy_pop_buffer()

A

-m

Pop up input buffer from buffer stack and then activate the input buffer at top of the buffer stack, return former active input buffer.

yy_new_filebuf(file, mode)

A

-m

Create a input buffer for file, interactive mode is set to mode (either true or false); file is name of a file or standard input if file is NULL.

yy_new_strbuf(buf, size)

A

-m

Create a input buffer for buf (a block of text of size size) without copying; size is number of characters contained in the block of text. It counts the terminal NULL.

yy_new_cstrbuf(buf, size)

A

-m

Copy buf (a block of text of size size), and create a input buffer for it; size is number of characters contained in the block of text. It counts the terminal NULL.

yy_delete_buffer()

A

-m

Delete active input buffer

yy_switch_buffer(pbuf)

A

-m

Save current active input buffer and then activate input buffer pbuf.

yyrestart()

A

-m

Reinitialize and rescan active input buffer; active input buffer is assumed to be random-access stream, e.g. normal files and string buffers; but standard input is not a random-access stream.

yyterminate()

A

-m

Terminate scanning.

yymore()

A

-m

Inform scanner not to overwrite yytext so that next matched text will begin at the end of current matched text.

yyless(n)

A

-m

Put all but first n characters back to active input buffer, so they will be rescanned during next match (es).

yyinput()

A

-m

Return next characters of active input buffer; END_OF_FILE (not EOF) returned indicates end of active input buffer is reached.

yyunput(c)

A

-m

Put back a character c into active input buffer.

yyunget()

A

-m

Put back last character return by yyinput into active input buffer; reverse the effect of a yyinput.

yyadd_lineno(nline)

A

+l –m

Increase line number by nline, nline can be negative.

yyadd_colno(ncol)

A

+l -m

Increase column number by ncol, ncol can be negative.

yyget_lineno()

A

+l -m

Return line number of next character

yyset_lineno(nline)

A

+l -m

Set line number of next character to be nline, nline should be positive.

yyget_colno()

A

+l -m

Return column number of next character

yyset_colno(ncol)

A

+l -m

Set column number of next character to be ncol, ncol should be positive.

yyget_tabsize()

A

+l -m

Return columns of tab.

yyset_tabsize(ntab)

A

+l -m

Set columns of tab to be ntab, ntab should be positive.

YYACCEPT()

B

-p

Indicate parser accepts the text inputted. The rest of text is remained unparsed.

YYABORT()

B

-p

Indicate parser stops working abnormally.

yyerrok()

B

-p

Indicate parser is back to normal mode again after error recovery. Be sure it is only called in error recovery actions.

yyerror(msg ...)

AB

-p

Default error report routine. It prints error message to the error/log stream of the parser which is specified by yysetstream. Its first argument msg is error message to be reported; and the rest is the same as yyparse/yylex. With option -l, and option -c for enabling column information, it will report location information where errors occurred as well.

It can be replaced by a user-defined error report routine of the same type by calling yyseterror with the new routine as its argument.

yysetstream(poutput, plogger)

C

None

Specify the output stream and the error/log stream of the parser. Its first argument poutput is the new output stream; and the second plogger is the new error/log stream. In C/C++, type of both of arguments is FILE*; In Object Pascal, the type is ptext_t which is defined as:

type ptext_t = ^text

Both of them can be empty (NULL in C/C++ and nil in Object Pascal). If poutput is empty, then messages that send to the output stream will be thrown away. And so is plogger. YYECHO/ECHO outputs matched text to the output stream specified by poutput. And yyerror sends error messages to the error/log stream specified by plogger. Debug information also is emitted to the error/log stream, when the parser in is debug mode (invoke upgen with option -D or -d)

If yysetstream is never called,the default values are used for both streams. In C/C++, the output stream will be stdout; and the error/log stream will be stderr. In Object Pascal, both of them are a pointer to OUTPUT.

For GUI programs in Object Pascal, it is essential to replace the default output stream and the error/log stream, because whenever a message is sent to them, an run-time exception will be raised.

yyseterror(perror)

C

None

Install user-defined error report routine to overwrite the default one. perror is an instance of yyerror_t.

yysetlex(plex)

C

-p

Install user-defined scanner’s controlling function. plex is and instance of yylex_t.

yyclearall()

C

None

Reset parser. After first calling of yyparse/yylex, it should be called before each calling of yyparse/yylex.

yylexfile(fname, imod)

C

-m

Initialize scanner whose input is from either standard input or a file. If fname is not empty, it is a legal name of file; otherwise, the input will be standard input. If imod is true, the scanner is in interactive mode; otherwise it is in non-interactive mode. When the scanner is in interactive mode, scanning will be interrupted by newlines. Interactive mode is often used for standard input.

yylexstr(pbuf, size)

C

-m

Initialize scanner whose input is from a string buffer containing a block of text. Comparing with yylexcstr, the scanner has not its own input buffer. pbuf is the block of text to be scanned. ; size is number of characters contained in the block of text. It counts the terminal NULL. It will return 0 if success, and non-zero error code otherwise.

yylexcstr(pbuf, size)

C

-m

Initialize scanner whose input is from a string buffer containing a block of text. Comparing with yylexstr, the scanner has its own input buffer. pbuf is the block of text to be scanned. ; size is number of characters contained in the block of text. It counts the terminal NULL. It will return 0 if success, and non-zero error code otherwise.

yylex(...)

C

-m

Controlling function of the built-in scanner.

Its arguments are specified by %formal-param and %actual-param. There are three types of return value: a positive integer standing for ID of the token just recognized, 0 indicating end of input, and negative integer standing for error code.

It can be replaced by a user-defined scanner of the same type of yylex by calling yysetlex. Be careful to do so, because all lexical rules and lexical special actions are disabled.

For a stand-alone scanner, yylex is the entry function called by other programs. If not, then yyparse is the entry function, which is responsible for calling yylex. Do not call yylex directly in the latter case.

yyparse(...)

C

-p

Controlling function of parser.

Its arguments are specified by %formal-param and %actual-param. It will return 0 if success, and non-zero error code otherwise.
